app.name: Rocks
app.info:
Rocks HD is a multi sensory exploration of rocks, soils, fossils, and minerals.

Designed to align with the common core science standards, the Rocks HD app helps learners answer questions like:

 - What is the rock cycle and what role does it play on Earth?

 - What are the different layers of the Earth? 

 - How is soil formed and what are the different horizons?

 - How are minerals formed and how are they extracted?

 - What is the difference between an index fossil and a trace fossil?



The Rocks HD app has been designed to provide multiple modes of learning that will make learning fun.

Features:

 ** HD photo based navigation provides an immersive learning experience. Swipe to naviagte.

** Curated photos and videos with descriptive text and free periodic refresh of photos and videos.

 ** Did You Know section with WOW facts about each topic.

 ** Easy, Intermediate and Advanced level questions based on Bloom's Taxonomy to test knowledge about the various topics. The quiz section has been designed to test not only remembering and understanding but also applying, evaluating, and analyzing the concepts.

 ** The Text section is enhanced with voice over for the beginning reader.


*****

 For more information on news and updates, like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter @SproutLabs.

*****

For feature requests, feedback or support, send email to support@sproutlabs.net

introTexts.item: Earth is made of many different types of rocks and minerals.
These rocks are formed, weathered down, cemented, and transformed to form new rocks in what is known as the Rock Cycle.
Minerals are elements or compounds that combine to form rocks.
Rocks and minerals combine with organic matter to form the top layer of the earth's surface known as soil.
Micro-organisms in the soil like bacteria and fungi break down plant and animal residues and convert them into nutrients for plants.
Fossils are remains of plants, animals and other living organisms that lived a long time ago.
These remains are preserved in rocks and help us understand Earth's history and provide clues about life in the distant past.

mainText.mainText:
Do you have a rock collection? If so, you already know how fascinating rocks can be! This lesson explains how rocks are formed, how they change, and how we use them. 
 What is a rock? Rocks are naturally occurring solid combinations of minerals and sometimes other materials too. The common rock granite is made of the minerals quartz, feldspar and biotite. When only one mineral is present, the object is a mineral, not rock. 
 Scientists classify rocks into three categories: Igneous, Sedimentary, and Metamorphic. These are all part of the rock cycle. 
 Igneous rocks begin deep in the Earth, which contains solid and molten materials such as silicon, magnesium and iron. Magma bursts through the Earth's surface via volcanoes and cracks in the Earth's crust. At the surface it's called lava. Lava hardens to become new crust. 
 Rocks are exposed to ocean waves and weather. They slowly break down into pebbles and sand. Sedimentary rocks are made of the resulting sand and mud, material from plants and animals, and minerals left over when liquid evaporates. These all compact and harden to become rock. 
 Metamorphic rocks are made when rocks experience new temperature and pressure conditions. For example, contact with magma could cause rock to liquify and then recrystallize into a different type of rock. 
 Scientists believe that humans have been using rocks for about 3.5 million years. Stone arrowheads were among our first tools. Today we mine rocks for use in roads, statues, buildings, chalkboards, jewelry, cosmetics and many other items.

item.name: rocks-4.png
item.title: Tropical Grasslands (Savanna)

item.text: Petrology is the study of the origin and composition of rocks.
Geology is the study of the Earth, rocks and the rock cycle.
A grain of sand is like a tiny rock! Look at one under a microscope.
Some rocks contain mineralites in addition to minerals. Glass is a mineralite.
Glass is made from superheated sand.
Igneous means fire in Latin. Igneous rocks come from magma.
When molten material cools inside the Earth's crust, intrusive rock is formed.
When lava cools outside the Earth's crust, extrusive rock is formed.
The Earth's outer rocky layer is called the lithosphere. It includes oceanic crust and continental crust.
Basalt is the most common rock on Earth. Much of the ocean's crust is basalt.
The Earth's continental crust is mainly andesite rock.
Marble is a metamorphic rock. It is usually made from limestone.
At least 300 degrees Fahrenheit (150 Celsius) are needed to cause metamorphic changes.
The Taj Mahal is made entirely of marble.
Geodes are ordinary-looking igneous or sedimentary rocks on the outside but contain beautiful crystals on the inside.
Meteorites, or rocks from outer space, help scientists learn about our solar system.
One of the oldest rocks on Earth was brought from the Moon. Scientists believe it is about 4.5 billion years old.
The Himalayas are among the world'€™s youngest mountains. Scientists estimate that they formed 30 million years ago.
To estimate the age of a sedimentary rock, scientists consider its thickness, mineral layers, and the plant and animal remains it may contain.
Mountains form when enormous pieces of the Earth's crust collide and bunch up.

item.title: The Life cycle of a Butterfly
Mountains are not eternal. They form when pieces of the Earth's crust collide and bunch up. Mountains will erode away.
item.description: Mountains are not eternal. They form when pieces of the Earth's crust collide and bunch up. Mountains will erode away.

item.question: For an object to be a rock in geologists' terms, what must it contain?
Creating sedimentary rocks primarily involves _________________.
Which rock type is most directly associated with molten (melted) material?
Which rocks are especially common in riverbeds?
Creating metamorphic rocks primarily involves _________________.

choice.answer: The compaction of sand and organic material

item.question: Judging from its name, sandstone is most likely ________.
Which event would most likely help create metamorphic rocks?
The Earth's crust __________.
Which rock would be most likely to contain glass?
Which of the following is true?
Which statement is true?

choice.answer: Oceanic crust is older than continental crust
Sedimentary rocks are not placed under pressure

item.question: To make a mountain, what must occur?
Oceanic crust is typically made through ________.
How would intrusive rock most likely reach the Earth's surface?

choice.answer: By filling cracks in the sea floor

item.question: If a planet did not have much weather, which rock type would take extra-long to form?

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Various stages of the rock cycle. Touch the glowing spots to learn more.

hotspot.title: Sedimentation
hotspot.text:
Sedimentation is the deposition of sediments resulting in the formation of sedimentary rock.

These sediments are broken down by erosion and weathering.

hotspot.title: Sedimentary rocks
hotspot.text:
Sedimentary rocks are formed when layers of sediments: minerals and particles accumulate on top of each other and are transformed by pressure into rock. 

Once the sediments have been formed by weathering and erosion, they are transported and deposited by wind (Aeolian or eolian process) water (fluvial process), glaciers, and ice. 

Sedimentary rocks are economically valuable compared to other rocks since they are a source of many fossil fuels and ores.

hotspot.title: Metamorphism
hotspot.text:
When physical or chemical changes result in a transformation and rearrangement of atoms in a rock into a new crystal structure, this process is known as Metamorphism. 

Pressure, heat, and fluids can cause metamorphism.

hotspot.title: Metamorphic rocks
hotspot.text:
Extreme heat and pressure can cause significant physical and/or chemical changes in a rock.

The process of metamorphism transforms existing rocks that can be igneous, metamorphic or sedimentary into metamorphic rocks. 

The original rock is known as the protolith.

hotspot.title: Melting
hotspot.text: The process through which a substance undergoes a phase transition from a solid to a liquid is known as melting.\n

hotspot.title: Magma
hotspot.text: Magma is a mixture of molten rock, solids, crystals, gases, and other chemicals, that is found beneath the surface of the Earth.\n

hotspot.title: Crystallization
hotspot.text:
A crystal is an ordered arrangement of atoms in a material. 

The process of forming solid crystals from a solution is known as crystallization.

hotspot.title: Igneous rocks
hotspot.text:
Igneous rocks are formed when lava or magma cool and solidify. 

Igneous rocks that are formed from magma are known as intrusive or plutonic rocks while those that are formed from lava are known as extrusive or volcanic rocks.

hotspot.title: Erosion
hotspot.text: Erosion is a natural process by which wind, water, glaciers, and ice remove soil and rock from the Earth's surface and move and deposit them in a different location.\n

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Lava flow cooling and hardening to form extrusive igneous rock or volcanic rock.

hotspot.title: Lava
hotspot.text:
Lava is molten rock that comes out of a volcano. After it cools and solidifies it forms igneous rock. 

Lava can be at very high temperatures ranging from approximately 1290F to over 2190F. 

In this picture, lava flow reaching the ocean is being cooled by the water to form a lava delta. Lava deltas can collapse without warning since they are very unstable. 

The steam produced when the lava and water react is very hot and can contain particles of volcanic rock.

hotspot.title: Igneous rock formation
hotspot.text:
Igneous rocks are formed when lava or magma cool and solidify. 

Igneous rocks that form from magma are also known as intrusive or plutonic rocks while those formed from lava are known as extrusive or volcanic rocks. 

There are three types of igneous rocks based on their composition: 

 1. Rocks with high amounts of silica and aluminum are known as felsic or silicic. 

 2. Rocks with lower amounts of silica and aluminum are known as intermediate or andesitic, 

 3. Rocks with high amounts of iron and magnesium are known as mafic or basaltic

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: The Earth is made of many different layers. Rocks are a part of the Earth's crust.

hotspot.title: Oceanic crust
hotspot.text:
Oceanic crust is formed when liquid lava cools quickly under the oceans. 

This is the outermost layer of the Earth's lithosphere.

hotspot.title: Continental crust
hotspot.text: The continental shelves and the igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks that make the continents are a part of the layer of the Earth known as the Continental crust.\n

hotspot.title: Lithosphere
hotspot.text:
Earth's lithosphere comprises the oceanic and continental crust and the outermost solid layer of the mantle. 

The Lithosphere is made up of the tectonic plates.

hotspot.title: Asthenosphere
hotspot.text:
Asthenosphere is the upper layer of the mantle and is located below the lithosphere.

It has rocks that can be deformed and is typically associated with large scale movement of the Earth's lithosphere or plate tectonics.

hotspot.title: Mantle
hotspot.text:
Over 80% of the Earth's volume is in the mantle. 

Did you know that the mantle is a rocky shell? 

The upper mantle starts at the base of the crust and extends to about 250 miles. It is made of magnesium and iron silicates such as olivine and pyroxene. 

The upper mantle is rigid on the top and is made of liquid rock below.

hotspot.title: Lower Mantle
hotspot.text:
The lower mantle contains silicon, magnesium and oxygen and has 50% of the mass of the planet. 

It is hotter and denser than the upper mantle.

hotspot.title: Inner core
hotspot.text:
The inner core is approximately 780 miles thick and is very hot (over 10,000F). 

Despite the extremely high temperature, the inner core is solid due to very high pressures.

hotspot.title: Outer core
hotspot.text:
The outer core is made of iron, nickel, sulfur, and oxygen. 

It is cooler than the inner core (7200-9000F) and is liquid.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: This picture shows the formation of the different types of igneous rock structures.

hotspot.title: Magmachamber or Batholith
hotspot.text:
This region shows a magmachamber or batholith, which means deep rock. 

When magma cools deep inside the Earth's crust and transforms into intrusive igneous or plutonic rock in a particular location it forms a batholith. 

Typically, batholiths are made of granite or quartz. Sometimes multiple individual rocks can converge to form a large mass of granite rock.

The Sierra Nevada Batholith that makes up a vast portion of the Sierra Nevada mountains in California is one such example.

hotspot.title: Dike
hotspot.text:
This region shows the formation of a dike. 

When there are cracks in existing rock, magma can force its way through. 

As the magma cools and solifies, it forms sheets of igneous rock that cut across the existing rocks.

hotspot.title: Laccolith
hotspot.text:
This region shows the formation of a laccolith. 

A laccolith is a sheet like formation of intrusive igneous rock between two layers of sedimentary rock. 

Since the magma has high pressure, it can force an upward movement of the existing sedimentary rock thus forming a dome or mushroom shape with a flat base.

hotspot.title: Pegmatite
hotspot.text:
A pegmatite is composed of crystalline, intrusive igneous rock that forms in the final stages of a magmachamber cooling and crystallization. 

As the magma cools to form rock, water is pushed out into molten rock and this water keeps getting concentrated with many different elements. 

In the final stages of cooling and crystallization, the water rich magma transforms into pegmatite containing large crystals of many rare minerals.

hotspot.title: Sill
hotspot.text:
This region shows a sill, which is a horizontal sheet of igneous rock between older layers of sedimentary or metamorphic rock. 

Unlike dikes in which the magma intrudes relatively vertical, sills are formed by relatively horizontal intrusion of magma.

hotspot.title: Stratovolcano
hotspot.text:
This region shows the processes associated with the formation of a stratovolcano also known as a composite volcano. 

A stratovolcano is typically a tall, conical volcano that is characterized by periods of explosive and quiet eruptions. 

Some stratovolcanoes can have collapsed craters and are called calderas. The Yellowstone caldera is a part of the Yellowstone Stratovolcano.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Igneous and metamorphic rocks can occur together as seen in this picture.

hotspot.title: Cape Spencer
hotspot.text:
This is a picture taken at Cape Spencer at the entrance to the Cross Sound near Juneau in the Glacier Bay National Park in Alaska.

This is the northernmost entrance to Alaska's Inland Passage.

hotspot.title: Igneous and metamorphic rocks
hotspot.text:
A combination of Igneous and metamorphic rocks is seen at Cape Spencer, Alaska. 

The picture also shows increased erosion by the water along the joined areas.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Travertine, a sedimentary rock, is formed in mineral springs.

hotspot.title: Travertine
hotspot.text:
Travertine is a type of sedimentary rock formed by precipitation of carbonate minerals. 

It is a type of natural stone like marble, slate, granite, and limestone.

Travertine typically forms in hot mineral springs and limetone caves and has different color and hardness compared to the other natural stones.

hotspot.title: Yellowstone
hotspot.text:
Yellowstone National Park was established in 1872 as the first National Park in the US. It is located mostly in Wyoming, but extends into Montana and Idaho. 

Yellowstone derives its name from the Yellowstone River, which in turn gets its name from the yellow colored rocky cliffs on its banks. 

Famous for its wildlife, geothermal features, and geology, Yellowstone is also part of the largest volcanic system in North America. 

The Yellowstone Caldera has been termed a stratovolcano because the caldera was formed by large explosive eruptions.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Nearly 40 sedimentary rock layers are exposed in the Grand Canyon.

hotspot.title: Grand Canyon
hotspot.text:
The Grand Canyon National Park represents one of the most complete sequences of rock on Earth. Nearly 40 major sedimentary rock layers are exposed in this area and range in age from about 200 million to nearly 2 billion years old. 

Most of these rocks were deposited in warm, shallow seas and near ancient sea shores in western North America. Both marine and terrestrial sediments are showcased, including fossilized sand dunes from an extinct desert.

The first sedimentary layer of rock, the Bass Formation was laid down 1.25 billion years ago. Fossils of Stromatolites or coastal algae are seen preserved in these rocks. 

Volcanic activity formed the Cardenas Basalt between 1.25 billion and 1.1 billion years ago. 

Coastal and shallow seas formed the Chuar group of rocks between 825 million and 1.1 billion years ago.

 Subsequent rock formations indicate a sequence of retreating oceans alternating with a coastal environment.

hotspot.title: Sedimentary rocks in Grand Canyon
hotspot.text:
The Kaibab limestone forms the topmost layer of rock and is the youngest rock found at the Grand Canyon National Park. This layer was formed when the Grand Canyon was a part of a warm, shallow sea with a sandy floor. 

Below the Kaibab, the Toroweap layer is made of the same material as the Kaibab but has a different color and was formed at a different time. 

The Coconino sandstones below the Toroweap layer are made of quartz and were formed from petrified sand dunes during a time when the the area was composed entirely of sand resulting in a desert like environment. 

The red colored cliffs of the Hermit Shale are rich in iron (hence the red color) and were formed when this region was part of a lagoon like environment with many swamps. This layer of rock has a lot of plant fossils.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Granite, an abundant igneous rock, is extracted from a quarry.

hotspot.title: Granite
hotspot.text:
Granite is a light colored, intrusive, igneous rock consisting of silicate based minerals like quartz, mica and feldspar. It is the most abundant rock in the continental crust. 

Granite rocks can get uplifted and exposed on the surface of the earth when the sedimentary rocks covering them are eroded. 

Granite is used in a variety of applications since it resists abrasion and weathering, it can be polished, and it can bear a lot of weight.

hotspot.title: Quarry
hotspot.text:
Rocks and minerals are extracted from a quarry, which is a type of open-pit mine. 

Open pit mines are used to extract rocks and minerals that are found near the surface of the Earth. Sand, gravel, building materials, and stones such as marble, sandstone, granite, limestone etc are quarried. 

The quarry stones, which are used for construction purposes, are cut into slabs before they are transported out of the quarry.

topic.name: minerals
topic.mainText:
What is a mineral? Minerals such as gold, calcium and sodium are the building blocks of rocks. They are inorganic. That is, although rocks may contain matter from plants and animals, minerals do not. Minerals are purely chemical. They are typically solid at room temperature. 
 Minerals are made of the elements listed on the Periodic Table. Minerals may consist of just one element, such as gold, or they can be combinations of elements. Quartz, for example, is made of silicon and oxygen. 
 Scientists classify minerals in several ways. Some categories are color, luster, hardness, specific gravity, and cleavage or how the mineral breaks. 
 When you are identifying minerals, color is helpful but not enough. Many minerals are found in multiple colors. Also, minerals may be impure; extra chemicals can change their color. Diamonds are made in every color of the rainbow. 
 "Luster" describes how a mineral reflects light. Some terms used to describe luster are brilliant, metallic, silky and dull. 
 Hardness is another way to classify a mineral. Hardness is measured by scratching a mineral. Diamonds are the hardest mineral on earth; they can scratch anything. 
 Specific gravity refers to density. Two mineral chunks of the same size can have different weights. Specific gravity can be measured by comparing a mineral's weight to an equal volume of water. 
 Cleavage and other characteristics of breakage help people classify minerals. For example, some crystals break with jagged edges. Others break along smooth planes. 
 People identify minerals in many other ways such as acid tests, radioactivity tests, and simply using their taste buds.

item.name: Desert-P1.png
item.title: Kalahari sub-tropical desert

item.text: Because elements can be combined in countless ways, scientists haven't set a limit on how many minerals exist.
The International Mineralogical Association recognizes approximately 4700 mineral species.
The most common mineral on Earth is quartz.
Amethyst, citrine and other types of quartz are the most common minerals used in jewelry.
The elements oxygen, silicon, aluminum, iron, magnesium, calcium, potassium, and sodium make up 98% of all minerals on Earth.
Mercury and water ice are exceptions to the rule that minerals are solid at room temperature.
The Mohs Hardness Scale is used to describe a mineral's hardness.
Because diamonds are so hard, they are useful in drill bits and other tools that cut.
Talc is the softest rock. It is used in body powder.
Crystals are minerals that have their atoms arranged in three-dimensional patterns.
Crystals are most likely to form when magma cools slowly and under great pressure.
When lava cools quickly, it is likely to form glassy rocks, not crystals.
Most of the Earth's crust is made of silicate minerals, which contain silicon and oxygen.
Eight important mineral groups are the silicates, native elements, sulfides, oxides, halides, carbonates, sulfates, and phosphates.
Native elements appear in nature uncombined with others. Examples are gold, silver and copper.
Halides are part halogen. Chloride and many other halides are salts.
Phosphates, which include the element phosphorus, are valued primarily as fertilizer and for detergents.
Heavy metal waste from phosphate mining has contaminated drinking water.
Sulfides, which combine sulfur with other minerals, may smell like rotten eggs. They are especially useful in medicine, art, and agriculture.
Diamonds and pencil lead€ are made from the same element: carbon. The look different because of their crystalline structure.

item.title: Title
Minerals such as gold are the building blocks of rocks. A picture of the Round Mountain Gold Mine in Nevada.
item.description: Minerals such as gold are the building blocks of rocks. A picture of the Round Mountain Gold Mine in Nevada.

item.title: Oxygen, silicon, aluminum, iron, magnesium, calcium, potassium, and sodium make up 98% of all minerals on Earth.
item.description: Oxygen, silicon, aluminum, iron, magnesium, calcium, potassium, and sodium make up 98% of all minerals on Earth.

item.title: Aluminum, the third most abundant mineral, makes up about 8% of the Earth's weight.
item.description: Aluminum, the third most abundant mineral, makes up about 8% of the Earth's weight.

item.title: Calcium, seen in the white rock here, is abundant too. It comprises pearls, eggshells, antacid tablets and your bones.
item.description: Calcium, seen in the white rock here, is abundant too. It comprises pearls, eggshells, antacid tablets and your bones.

item.title: Sodium silicate, meanwhile, makes up much of the Earth's crust.
item.description: Sodium silicate, meanwhile, makes up much of the Earth's crust.

item.title: Minerals like these are all inorganic. That is, minerals do not contain plant or animal materials.
item.description: Minerals like these are all inorganic. That is, minerals do not contain plant or animal materials.

item.title: For example, quartz is made entirely of silicon and oxygen.
item.description: For example, quartz is made entirely of silicon and oxygen.

item.title: Quartz is the most common mineral on Earth.
item.description: Quartz is the most common mineral on Earth.

item.title: Amethyst, a type of quartz, is popular for jewelry. But how can we tell all the stones apart?
item.description: Amethyst, a type of quartz, is popular for jewelry. But how can we tell all the stones apart?

item.title: We classify minerals by sight but that's not enough. Diamonds, for instance, occur in many colors.
item.description: We classify minerals by sight but that's not enough. Diamonds, for instance, occur in many colors.

item.title: Minerals are also categorized by luster. Luster describes how a mineral reflects light.
item.description: Minerals are also categorized by luster. Luster describes how a mineral reflects light.

item.description: The Moh's Hardness Test involves scratching a mineral to identify it.

item.description: Diamond is the hardest mineral.

item.title: Mineral cleavage refers to how a mineral breaks. It is another clue for mineral classification.
item.description: Mineral cleavage refers to how a mineral breaks. It is another clue for mineral classification.

item.title: Fluorescent and radioactive tests also help scientists identify minerals.
item.description: Fluorescent and radioactive tests also help scientists identify minerals.

item.title: Minerals take many forms. Mercury is one of the few minerals that is liquid at room temperature.
item.description: Minerals take many forms. Mercury is one of the few minerals that is liquid at room temperature.

item.title: Diamonds and pencil graphite are both made of carbon. Diamonds are carbon crystals. Graphite is carbon sheets.
item.description: Diamonds and pencil graphite are both made of carbon. Diamonds are carbon crystals. Graphite is carbon sheets.

item.title: Citrine, diamonds and other crystals are most likely to form when magma cools slowly.

item.title: Minerals should be used responsibly. One risk is phosphates. These are used in fertilizers and detergents but contaminate drinking water.

item.question: How are minerals related to rocks?

choice.answer: In geology, minerals and rocks are synonyms.
Rocks are the building blocks of minerals.

item.question: What is luster?
The way a mineral divides is called ________.
Which mineral is the most abundant on Earth?
Which is a native mineral?
What causes a diamond to be colorful?
Why does a diamond's carbon look different from a pencil's carbon?

choice.answer: Pencil carbon has been exposed to higher temperatures
Pencil carbon is mixed with phosphates

item.question: What effect do high heat and pressure have upon minerals?

choice.answer: They increase the likelihood of contamination

item.question: Why are diamonds considered more valuable than glass?
Which sense can help us identify minerals?
What is an important difference between minerals and rocks?

choice.answer: Minerals do not contain organic material
Rocks do not contain organic material
Minerals are not recycled by the Earth

item.question: Which characteristic helps make mercury a mineral?

choice.answer: It is solid at room temperature

item.question: If a unknown item is a gas, it is most likely ___________.
If a planet did not have any oxygen, it would also lack _______.
What is the most reliable way to tell whether a gemstone is real or imitation diamond?

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Open pit mines are used to extract minerals that are found near the surface.

hotspot.title: Open pit mine
hotspot.text:
Open pit mines are used to extract rocks and minerals that are found near the surface of the Earth. 

The mines start small and then keep getting larger until the mineral resource has been completely extracted or it becomes difficult to mine. 

What happens to the land after the mine has been exhausted?

At the end of it life, an open pit mine is rehabilitated or returned to is former state. Mines are covered with soil and then vegetation is planted.

hotspot.title: Udachnaya diamond mine
hotspot.text:
Udachnaya means lucky in Russian. The Udachnaya pipe is an open pit diamond mine and is a part of the Mir pipe. 

The volcanic rock kimberlite is typically associated with diamond deposits as well as garnets and spinels. 

Kimberlite pipes are formed as a result of eruption of deep volcanoes and have the shape of a carrot that rises from a dike.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Kalgoorlie Super pit is Australia's largest open cut gold mine.

hotspot.title: Kalgoorlie gold mine
hotspot.text:
The Kalgoorlie Super Pit or the Fimiston Open Pit is Australia's largest open cut gold mine. 

Over 80% of the gold in this mine is found in host rocks that are part of what is known as the Golden Mile Dolerite or the richest mile on Earth. 

Every year over 85 million tons of materials is moved from the pit of which 12 million tons is material that has gold.

hotspot.title: Australia, Kalgoorlie Super pit
hotspot.text:
Fluids containing gold and minerals are formed deep inside the Earth's crust and are forced up into fractures in the rock during tectonic activity, where the gold eventually crystallizes.

The gold formed in Kalgoorlie during a period of intense intrusion of igneous rock and metamorphism.

Gold has been discovered on every continent but is very rare. 80% of the world's gold is still in the ground.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: The Kittila gold mine in Finland is located beneath volcanic and sedimentary rocks.

hotspot.title: Kittila mine
hotspot.text:
Located in the Lapland province of northern Finland, Kittila is an open pit and underground gold mine that is a part of the Suurikuusikko gold deposit.

The Kittile mine is one of the largest gold producing mines in Europe and is located beneath volcanic and sedimentary rocks.

hotspot.title: Kittila gold mine
hotspot.text:
Gold is a precious metal that is bright yellow in color and does not get oxidized in air or water. 

It occurs in nature in the form of nuggets or grains since it is less reactive.

Due to its high density, most of the gold is located in the core of the Earth.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Diamond and graphite are allotropes (pure forms) of carbon with different crystal structures.

hotspot.title: Diamond
hotspot.text:
In diamond, the carbon atoms are arranged at the corners of a tetrahedron. 

Each carbon atom is attached or bonded to four other carbon atoms through covalent bonds. 

This crystal structure gives diamond its hardness. Diamond is the hardest material known.

hotspot.title: Graphite
hotspot.text:
In graphite, the carbon atoms are arranged as layers of infinite atoms. The atoms are arranged at the corners of a hexagon and are held together by covalent bonds.

The bond between the layers is, however, very weak.

This layered structure makes graphite smooth and slippery and hence it is used as a lubricant.

hotspot.title: Graphite
hotspot.text:
Graphite is an allotrope of carbon.

It is gray or black in color and is a softer, crystalline form of carbon.

It occurs in metamorphic rocks that are rich in carbon.

It can sometimes be found in pegmatites.

hotspot.title: Diamond
hotspot.text:
Diamond is an allotrope of carbon and is the hardest known material.

It is typically found in Kimberlite pipes where it is brought to the surface from the mantle where it is formed.

Due to its rigid structure, diamond occurs in a pure form giving it a colorless appearance.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Ruby is a precious stone made of Aluminum oxide that is found in marble stone.

hotspot.title: Ruby
hotspot.text:
Ruby is a precious stone along with diamond, sapphire, and emerald.

It is made of Aluminum oxide. 

 The pink or blood red color is caused by the presence of Chromium.

 Did you know that sapphire is also a form of Aluminum oxide? 

In sapphire, the presence of small amounts of Titanium give the stone a brilliant blue color.

hotspot.title: Ruby rock
hotspot.text:
Ruby is found mostly embedded in marble.

First limestone needs to metamorphose into marble.

Subsequently, as molten granite pushes its way into the marble, it removes silica and leaves behind aluminum and oxygen that form the ruby.

Did you know that ruby formation has been associated with the formation of the Himalayas. Most of the world's rubies are found in areas near the Himalayas.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Minerals can be identified using fluorescence.

hotspot.title: Fluorescence
hotspot.text: Chemicals in the minerals can absorb UV radation and emit radiation in the visible wavelengths that we can see.\n\nTypically, if a mineral is pure and has no contaminants, then it will not fluoresce.

hotspot.title: Mineral identification
hotspot.text:
Scientists use many different ways to identify minerals.

Color, hardness, luster, streaks, specific gravity etc are some mineral properties that are used to identify various minerals.

Fluorescence is another technique to identify minerals.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Gemstone pebbles occur in many colors, shapes, and textures.

hotspot.title: Color
hotspot.text:
Minerals have different colors based on the chemical contaminant.

Chromium in Aluminum oxide produces red color, while titanium produces the blue color when present in Aluminum oxide.

hotspot.title: Gems
hotspot.text:
Crystals that have no defects can be cut and polished into gems.

These semi precious or precious stones can be used to make jewelry and other items.

Certain rocks that are not minerals and some organic materials like amber are also considered gemstones.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: A collection of various gemstones. Touch the glowing spots to learn more.

hotspot.title: Lazurite
hotspot.text:
Lazurite derives its name from the Persian word, Lazhward, meaning blue. 

It is also known as ultramarine and is a component of Lapis Lazuli, which is a rock made of lazurite, calcite (calcium carbonte) and pyrite (iron sulfide). 

It is formed in metamorphosed limestone.

hotspot.title: Tigers Eye
hotspot.text:
Tiger's eye is a metamorphic rock that is golden or red brown in color. 

It is a type of quartz and exhibits a cat's eye effect because of parallel growth of quartz crystals between limonite.

hotspot.title: Moss agate
hotspot.text:
Moss agate is formed from volcanic rocks. It is a semi-precious gemstone also known as mocha stone. 

Primarily made of silicon dioxide, the green filament patterns resemble moss growing on a stone and hence the name.

hotspot.title: Sodalite
hotspot.text:
A royal blue ornamental gemstone, sodalite, has high sodium content and hence the name. 

Although similar to lazurite and lapis lazuli, it does not contain pyrite. It is found in plutonic igenous rocks.

hotspot.title: Aragonite
hotspot.text:
Aragonite is a form of calcium carbonate.

It is crystalline in nature, but has a different crystal structure compared to calcite.

Since Aragonite is unstable, it converts to calcite over very long periods of time.

hotspot.title: Serpentine
hotspot.text:
Serpentine minerals are typically olive green in color and are thus also known as Serpent rock.

These rocks are made of silicates of magnesium and iron that combine in the presence of water to form rock.

hotspot.title: Unakite
hotspot.text: A semiprecious granite-based stone that occurs in shades of green and pink, Unakite is used to make jewelry and other decorative items.\n

topic.name: soil
topic.mainText:
Soil is like a nutrition bar for plants. It holds all the nutrients that plants need to survive. Soil has developed over hundreds of millions of years. It is created as weather erodes rocks and when plants and animals leave material behind. Minerals mix with organic material and water to become soil. 
 Much of soil is alive! Bacteria, algae and fungi in soil break material into useful nutrients. They make it possible for larger life forms to survive. 
 The Earth's soil is organized into several layers called horizons. The topmost layer contains humus, which is leaf litter and decomposed organic matter. The next layer is topsoil. This is where seeds germinate and roots grow. It has sediment from rocks and contains some humus too. 
 The next layer down is called the eluviation layer. It is light colored, made mostly of sand and silt. Most minerals and clay drip down to the subsoil below. Subsoil is rich with clay and minerals from water, such as iron and calcium carbonate. 
 The bottommost layers are rocky. First there is regolith. Regolith is a mix of broken bedrock and dark soil, which is composed of dead organic matter. A solid layer of bedrock lays beneath it all. 
 Erosion is the carrying away of rocks and soil. Erosion is caused by wind, precipitation and gravity. Although erosion is a natural process, it is problematic when we lose soil for crops, forests and other habitats. Trees can help fight erosion because their roots stabilize the soil.

item.name: Forests-P1.png
item.title: Rainforest canopy

item.text: Soil formation is called pedogenesis.
Soil is heavily influenced by its environment. Important factors include climate, relief (slope), local organisms, local minerals, and time.
Most of the Earth's soil is younger than 2.5 million years old.
Soil is classified by size. Clay soil is made of especially small particles. That's why it can filter to the bottom of the soil horizons.
Silt particles are slightly larger than clay particles.
Common minerals in soil are quartz, feldspar, calcite and mica.
From a gardening perspective, a good soil contains about 45% minerals (sand, silt and clay), 25% water, and 5% organic material. The rest is air!
Water is important to the effectiveness of soil. The pH or acidity of soil affects the availability of nutrients to plants.
Liquid water and glaciers can carry soil thousands of miles.
Wind can move sand and silt hundreds of miles.
When land is steep, soil is less able to hold minerals; they run off.
Fall colors are due to plants withdrawing chlorophyll from their leaves during shortening days of fall.
Soil may contain more than a million species of microbes per gram!
It takes about 800 to 1000 years for nature to create an inch of soil.
Nowadays, because of certain farming practices, one inch of topsoil is lost about every 28 years.
Soil stores about 10% of the world's carbon dioxide emissions.
Creatures living in the soil are classified as macrofauna, mesofauna and microfauna.
Examples of macrofauna are worms, beetles and termites.
Mesofauna include mites and nematodes.
The tiniest creatures in the soil are protozoa and other microfauna.

item.title: Metamorphosis
Countless varieties of soil can be found around the Earth.
item.description: Countless varieties of soil can be found around the Earth.

item.title: Scientists study soil to make better decisions for solving hunger and urban growth.
item.description: Scientists study soil to make better decisions for solving hunger and urban growth.

item.title: Soil holds all the nutrients that plants need to survive.
item.description: Soil holds all the nutrients that plants need to survive.

item.description: Soil is created as weather erodes rocks.

item.title: Decay from plants and animals also contributes to soil.

item.title: Soil is organized into several layers called horizons.

item.title: The topmost layer, humus, is leaf litter and decomposed organic matter.
item.description: The topmost layer, humus, is leaf litter and decomposed organic matter.

item.title: Topsoil is where seeds germinate and roots grow. It has sediment from rocks and contains some humus too.

item.title: Although sand is mainly below the topsoil, topsoil can also be sandy.

item.title: Clay is found beneath topsoil and sand in the subsoil horizon.
item.description: Clay is found beneath topsoil and sand in the subsoil horizon.

item.title: This soil in Brazil is rich with clay.
item.description: This soil in Brazil is rich with clay.

item.title: Termites are a type of macrofauna that live in topsoil. They help make nutrients available.
item.description: Termites are a type of macrofauna that live in topsoil. They help make nutrients available.

item.title: Nematodes are mesofauna. They also break matter down into nutrients for plants.
item.description: Nematodes are mesofauna. They also break matter down into nutrients for plants.

item.title: Roots absorb nutrients from the topsoil.
item.description: Roots absorb nutrients from the topsoil.

item.title: A heavy river washes away topsoil in Ethiopia.

item.title: The effects of wind erosion can be seen at Lake Tecumseh.

item.title: Glaciers also erode. They can carry boulders and soil thousands of miles.

item.title: Soil regulates our environment by absorbing carbon dioxide. Protecting soil can help prevent global warming.

item.question: What is soil made of?
What is humus?
Where is most clay located?
Which of these forces causes soil erosion?
What are the major layers of soil called?
Why is soil essential to life?

choice.answer: Plants do not grow in sandy areas.
Soil is the source of all bacteria.

item.question: Why does soil take so long to form?

choice.answer: Rock erosion is a slow process.
Most minerals seep into the Earth.

item.question: According to the narrator, how is soil alive?

choice.answer: It moves with the help of natural forces.
It contains very small life forms.
It is part of the rock cycle.

item.question: Why don't we see all the minerals in soil?

choice.answer: Minerals comprise a tiny percentage of good soil.
The minerals are present as small particles.
Minerals are only present in subsoil.

item.question: How does soil become layered?

choice.answer: Materials fall according to size and weight.

item.question: What is a possible consequence of erosion?

choice.answer: Algae and fungi will be washed away.

item.question: How does the eluviation layer compare to regolith?

choice.answer: The eluviation layer is lighter in color.
The eluviation layer is darker in color.

item.question: How would relief or slope most likely influence a region's topsoil?

choice.answer: A steep region would have more topsoil.
A steep region would have less topsoil.
A steep region would have richer topsoil.
A steep region would have darker topsoil.

item.question: How would deforestation influence an area's soil?

choice.answer: Soil erosion would become less likely.
Soil erosion would become more likely.

item.question: How is subsoil different from topsoil?

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Soil is made up of layers parallel to the surface known as horizons.

hotspot.title: Humus
hotspot.text:
The top, organic layer of soil is made up mostly of leaf litter and humus (decomposed organic matter).

 It is known as the O layer or the organic horizon.

hotspot.title: A Horizon
hotspot.text:
A Horizon is the layer called topsoil. 

It is found below the O horizon and above the E or B horizon.

Seeds germinate and plant roots grow in this dark-colored layer. 

It is made up of humus (decomposed organic matter) mixed with mineral particles.

hotspot.title: E Horizon
hotspot.text:
E Horizon derives its name from eluviation or leaching. 

This layer is light in color and is beneath the A Horizon and above the B Horizon. 

It is made up mostly of sand and silt, having lost most of its minerals and clay as water drips through the soil.

hotspot.title: B Horizon
hotspot.text:
B Horizon is also called the subsoil.

This layer is beneath the E Horizon and above the C Horizon. 

It contains clay and mineral deposits (iron, aluminum oxides, and calcium carbonate).

It receives these materials from the layers above it when mineralized water drips from the soil above.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: There are many different types of soils.

hotspot.title: Peaty soil
hotspot.text:
Peaty soil is generally found in marshy areas. 

Since it is formed by the accumulation and decay of organic matter, peaty soil contains more organic material than most of the soils but has less nutrients.

hotspot.title: Clay soil
hotspot.text:
Clay soil is formed from the accumulation of sedimentary deposits from the erosion of rock.

Clay soil has fine grained material and less air space.

It is thus prone to water logging and has poor drainage.

A lot of fertilizers need to be added to make clay soil cultivable.

hotspot.title: Sandy soil
hotspot.text:
Sandy soil has small rock and mineral particles and is formed from the erosion of limestone, granite, quartz and other types of rocks.

If sandy soil has lots of organic material then it can be used for culitvation. 

Since it does not retain moisture that can cause root decay, sandy soil is generally good for plants

hotspot.title: Chalky soil
hotspot.text:
Chalky soil is alkaline in nature and is prone to dryness. 

It requires more watering and fertilizing than any other type of soil. 

Since it blocks nutrients for the plants, it is often not considered a good soil for plantation.

hotspot.title: Loamy soil
hotspot.text:
Considered the perfect soil and ideal for cultivation, loamy soil consists of sand, silt and clay. 

Due to its texture, it can retain water easily while allowing good drainage.

hotspot.title: Silty soil
hotspot.text:
Silty soil is composed of organic material and minerals like quartz. 

It has more nutrients than sandy soil. 

Silty soil is considered to be the most fertile soil. It is ideal for cultivation since it offers good drainage.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Termites play an important role in soil formation and nutrient cycling.

hotspot.title: Termite mound
hotspot.text:
Termites play a very important role in nutrient cycling of dead plant material by breaking down cellulose. 

They also help in soil formation and movement and transportation of soil material.

hotspot.title: Termite ecosystem
hotspot.text:
Like earthworms on farmland, termites aerate the surrounding soil, allowing more water to penetrate. 

This activity, along with termite droppings, creates highly fertile patches of earth with a higher percentage of nitrogen and phosphorous than the ground farther away. 

The termite mounds thus have been shown to sustain significantly more shrubs, fruit-bearing trees, bugs, and animals in the African savanna.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Limestone towers at Mono Lake formed from dissolved salts in the runoff water.

hotspot.title: Tufa
hotspot.text:
The limestone towers seen in the picture are made mostly of calcite (calcium carbonate) deposited in the salty and alkaline water of the Mono Lake, in California. 

These rocks formed under water when calcium-rich spring water at the bottom of the lake bubbled up into the alkaline lake, forming these calcite "tufa" towers. 

When the lake level drops, the tufa towers appear in interesting formations.

hotspot.title: Mono lake
hotspot.text:
Mono Lake lies in the landlocked Mono Basin where any dissolved salts in the runoff water remain in the lake and increase the pH levels and salt concentration. 

The basin was created by geological forces over the last five million years.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Delicate arch formed by weathering and erosion of sandstone by wind and water.

hotspot.title: Delicate arch
hotspot.text:
The widely recognized Delicate Arch is a natural arch 65ft tall. 

It is located in the Arches National Park near Moab, Utah. 

Composed of Entrada Sandstone from the Jurassic period, the arch was formed by a combination of weathering and erosion.

hotspot.title: Arches National Park
hotspot.text:
Arches National Park was formed over an underground salt bed known as the Paradox formation. 

Layers of sediments were deposited onto this salt bed over millions of years and were converted into rock. 

As the salt bed buckled due to the weight of the sandstones, it led to the formation of domes and cavities. 

Subsequently, weathering and erosion of these rocks due to water, ice, and wind lead to the formation of some of the magnificent structures seen at the Arches National Park.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Structures formed by the weathering and erosion of rock by wind and water.

hotspot.title: Delicate arch
hotspot.text:
The widely recognized Delicate Arch is a natural arch 65ft tall. 

It is located in the Arches National Park near Moab, Utah. 

Composed of Entrada Sandstone from the Jurassic period, the arch was formed by a combination of weathering and erosion.

hotspot.title: Courthouse towers
hotspot.text:
The Courthouse towers are tall columns of stone rising to 4800ft that were a part of the Entrada Sandstone. 

Weathering by wind and water formed the arches and spires.

hotspot.title: Balanced rock
hotspot.text:
Balanced rock is one of the famous landmarks of the Arches National Park. 

The top rock is the size of three school buses.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Plants can help prevent erosion by wind and water.

hotspot.title: Plants prevent erosion
hotspot.text:
Plants help prevent erosion by providing vegetative cover, decreasing runoff, and protecting the soil from wind resulting in lower wind erosion. 

Further, the roots hold the soil together reducing water and wind erosion.

hotspot.title: Erosion by water
hotspot.text:
There are different ways water can erode the landscape. 

In sheet erosion particles loosened by rain splash are transported by flow of water. 

If the erosion happens due to flowing rivulets, it is known as Rill erosion.

Large channels of water can cause Gully erosion.

 Rivers, streams and waves can also cause erosion.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Glaciers can erode rocks by abrasion and fracturing.

hotspot.title: Glaciers
hotspot.text:
Glaciers are frozen rivers of ice and sediments that flow downhill. 

As snow falls, it compresses the layers below to form ice. If the ice is formed on a slope, then this massive sheet of ice and snow begins to slowly move downhill. 

Most glaciers are found near the poles but they also exits on all the continents.

hotspot.title: Glacial erosion
hotspot.text:
When glaciers flow over rocks, the ice and sediments in the glacier can act as a sandpaper and pulverize the rock below. This process is known as abrasion. 

Abrasion can lead to the formation of deep valleys and mountain slopes. 

Glaciers can also soften and remove blocks of rock. This happens because the water in the glacier can penetrate cracks in the rock.

As the water freezes, it expands leading to a fracture in the rock.

mainText.mainText:
Fossils are remains and signs of ancient living things. They are the only evidence we have that certain species existed. Fossils reveal a history of the Earth's earliest bacteria, flowers, fish and other life. 
 Not everything that dies becomes a fossil; most plants and animals are soon recycled by nature. But sometimes life is preserved in its entirety as a whole fossil. For a whole fossil to occur, a creature must be buried away from all oxygen. This might happen with help from a mudflow, glacier or tree sap. 
 Compared with whole fossils, cast fossils are more common. Bones, tree trunks and other remains become cast fossils when their organic matter decays and is replaced with minerals. A fossilized bone no longer contains bone material; it has all been replaced! Depending on which minerals fill the mold, a cast fossil may look like dull cement or have spectacular sparkle. 
 A third type of fossil is the mold fossil. A mold fossil is an impression of the organism. We know about certain plants and animals simply because of impressions they left. 
 Finally, a trace fossil is other evidence that an organism existed. Fossilized nests, footprints, and animal dung are examples of trace fossils. 
 Fossils are constantly weathered or even destroyed by nature. For instance, fossils are lost when rocks undergo metamorphosis. Sometimes though, when erosion and other factors work together, fossils are revealed or become easier to access during geologic expeditions.

item.name: Grassland-P1.png
item.title: Tropical Grasslands (Savanna)

item.text: The word fossil comes from the Latin word fossilis, which means "dug up."
Paleontology is the study of life from former geologic periods. Paleontologists primarily study fossils.
The fossil record is sparse until about 600 million years ago.
The study of the fossilization process is called taphonomy.
When organisms fall to the sea floor, they can quickly become covered with sediment. Most fossils are excavated from sedimentary rock layers.
Ammonites are the most widely known fossil. Fossils suggest that spiral-shelled ammonites lived in the oceans until 65 million years ago.
A few places on Earth are especially known for preserving ancient life. They are called lagerstatten.
The oldest animal fossils come from the Burgess Shale in Canada and the Chengjiang Deposits in China.
Whole woolly mammoth fossils were found in 2012. Siberian scientists believe they could use DNA to revive this extinct species!
Whole fossils of leaves can preserve autumn colors from millions of years ago.
Fossils suggest that a gigantic shark lived between two million and 16 million years ago. The megalodon was 50 feet long.
The largest dinosaur fossil is of a sauroposeidon. Fossils suggest that sauroposeidons were 56 feet tall!
Carefully unearthing a large dinosaur fossil can take years. Tools used range from dental scrapers to sledgehammers.
According to the fossil record, the smallest avian dinosaur (or flying dinosaur) was about the size of a crow.
Paleontologists estimate the weight of ancient animals by measuring the depth of fossilized footprints.
Coprolites, or fossilized feces, can tell us what an animal ate.
Mold fossils can be filled with wax to make an impression that has the shape of the original life form.
By studying how rocks are layered, we can tell which rocks are the oldest. This helps us understand the fossils they hold.
Index fossils are those about which much is known. When an index fossil is found, it can provide clues about other fossils nearby.
Fossils are at least 10,000 years old. The oldest fossils found are approximately 3.5 billions years old.

item.title: The Life cycle of a Butterfly
Fossils like these are remains or signs of ancient life.
item.description: Fossils like these are remains or signs of ancient life.

item.title: This fossil of the megalodon's jaws suggests that it was the world's largest predatory fish.
item.description: This fossil of the megalodon's jaws suggests that it was the world's largest predatory fish.

item.title: Some of the oldest fossils we've found come from the Burgess Shale in Canada.
item.description: Some of the oldest fossils we've found come from the Burgess Shale in Canada.

item.title: By studying how rocks are layered, we can tell which of their fossils are the oldest.
item.description: By studying how rocks are layered, we can tell which of their fossils are the oldest.

item.title: Trilobites are index fossils. Since we know a lot about when they are from, they are clues about nearby fossils.
item.description: Trilobites are index fossils. Since we know a lot about when they are from, they are clues about nearby fossils.

item.title: Trilobite fossils are found in sedimentary rock.
item.description: Trilobite fossils are found in sedimentary rock.

item.title: So called whole fossils like these are created when oxygen quickly leaves an environment.
item.description: So called whole fossils like these are created when oxygen quickly leaves an environment.

item.title: Tree sap has helped create whole fossils.
item.description: Tree sap has helped create whole fossils.

item.title: Another fossil type is the cast fossil. This Australopithecus cast fossil was created when minerals replaced the original material.
item.description: Another fossil type is the cast fossil. This Australopithecus cast fossil was created when minerals replaced the original material.

item.title: Ammonites are among the most common mold fossils. These may also fill with minerals.
item.description: Ammonites are among the most common mold fossils. These may also fill with minerals.

item.title: Fossils suggest that spiral-shelled ammonites lived in the oceans until 65 million years ago.
item.description: Fossils suggest that spiral-shelled ammonites lived in the oceans until 65 million years ago.

item.title: A variety of tools are used on dinosaur digs and other fossil expeditions.
item.description: A variety of tools are used on dinosaur digs and other fossil expeditions.

item.title: A paleontologist makes a mold of a dinosaur fossil found in Montana.
item.description: A paleontologist makes a mold of a dinosaur fossil found in Montana.

item.title: Scientists keep their dinosaur finds arranged in trays.
item.description: Scientists keep their dinosaur finds arranged in trays.

item.title: Dinosaur tracks are an example of trace fossils.
item.description: Dinosaur tracks are an example of trace fossils.

item.title: Trace fossils like dinosaur tracks tell us about animal size and behavior.
item.description: Trace fossils like dinosaur tracks tell us about animal size and behavior.

item.title: Coprolites can tell us about the animal's anatomy and diet.
item.description: Coprolites can tell us about the animal's anatomy and diet.

item.title: Cast fossils tell us about the T. Rex's incredible size!
item.description: Cast fossils tell us about the T. Rex's incredible size!

item.question: What is needed to create a whole fossil?
When a tree trunk decays and its shape is replaced with minerals, it becomes a _______.
Woolly mammoth tracks are examples of ________.
Where are most fossils found?
What can we learn from fossils?

choice.answer: The shape of an animal's body

item.question: Why might fossils of the same species look different from each other?

choice.answer: They are made of different minerals.
Different amounts of oxygen were available during formation.

item.question: In general, which fossils give the best clues about animal behavior?
Since countless plants and animals have died, why isn't the Earth flooded with fossils?

choice.answer: Fossils are destroyed when rocks undergo metamorphic change.
Fossils are broken down by nature.
Not everything that dies becomes a fossil.

item.question: Why do many fossils come from the sea floor? Choose the best answer.

choice.answer: Land animals are washed out to sea.
Sea creatures are easily buried by sediment.
Most species live in the ocean.

item.question: Why are rock layers useful in the study of fossils?

choice.answer: They give clues about the organism's time period.
They are most likely to hold whole fossils.

item.question: What is most likely about a lagerstatten?

choice.answer: It is in a warm climate.
It has high low oxygen levels.

item.question: To make a mountain, what must occur?
What best explains the great number of ammonite fossil discoveries?

choice.answer: Ammonites' shells made cast fossilization possible.
Ammonites lived where many people live today.
Ammonites were preserved by tree sap or amber.

item.question: In the Grand Canyon, where are the oldest fossils most likely to be?

choice.answer: In the highest layers of rock
In the lowest layers of rock

item.question: The fossil record is sparse until about 600 million years ago. What explains this best?

choice.answer: Much more oxygen was present until 600 million years ago.
Lava has covered the older animal fossils.
Life became much more plentiful about 600 million years ago.
Sedimentary rock was not created until 600 million years ago.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Amber is sticky tree sap that can fossilize insects.

hotspot.title: Amber
hotspot.text:
Amber starts out as sticky tree sap that helps protect the plants from insects and helps to seal the plant's wounds. 

As it hardens over time, insects and other organisms that get stuck in the resin, get fossilized.

hotspot.title: Fossil
hotspot.text:
Fossilized tree resin or Amber can fossilize parts of an organism including small DNA fragments that are otherwise hard to preserve. 

The fossil resins can contain bacteria, fungi, insects, and plants. 

Some of the oldest ambers recovered are over 130 million years old.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Fossilized fern from the Coal Age, over 300-360 millions ago.

hotspot.title: Fern
hotspot.text: This is a picture of a fossilized leaf of the fern Pecopteris arborescens from the Upper Carboniferous period over 300-360 million years ago.\n

hotspot.title: Coal
hotspot.text:
This fossil is from the coal age or the Upper Carboniferous period. 

Bark bearing trees with lignin first appeared during this period. 

When plants died and decayed, they became buried and compressed by new organic material growing on top of them, forming thick layers of coal.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Petrified wood or wood that has been turned to stone.

hotspot.title: Petrified wood
hotspot.text:
Petrified wood means wood turned into rock or stone. 

This picture shows a petrified wood sample where the organic materials in the tree have been replaced by minerals like quartz, while maintaining the original look and shape.

hotspot.title: Formation of petrified wood
hotspot.text:
Petrified wood is unique because it is a three dimensional representation of a fossil. 

When wood is covered with sediment under the ground in an environment without oxygen, it cannot be decomposed.

Water flowing through the sediments can slowly replace the organic materials with minerals. 

It can take over a 100 years to convert wood to petrified wood.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Fossilized seeds of the Katsura tree preserved in volcanic ash and limestone.

hotspot.title: Seeds of Katsura
hotspot.text:
The Katsura is an ornamental tree found in Japan and China.

It has heart shaped leaves with bright yellow, orange, or red colors.

This picture shows a fossil of the seeds of a Katsura tree.

Found in Denmark and dating back to 55 million years ago, this fossil was formed during the marine geological formation call the Fur Formation.

hotspot.title: Fur formation
hotspot.text:
The Fur formation in Denmark is a marine geological formation dating back to 55 million years ago.

This formation has diatoms (a type of algae) and clay covered with volcanic ash and limestone.

Lots of fossilized fish, insects, plants, and birds are seen in the rocks.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: A trace fossil showing dinosaur footprints

hotspot.title: Trace fossil showing dinosaur footprints.
hotspot.text:
A trace fossil showing dinosaur footprints. 

Trace fossils are formed when an organism leaves impressions on an underlying substrate.

hotspot.title: Trace fossils
hotspot.text:
Trace fossils are best preserved in sandstones. 

They can also form in shale and limestone. 

Unlike other fossils which are formed after the organism dies, trace fossils are created when the organism was alive.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: A dinosaur fossil showing well preserved teeth.

hotspot.title: Dinosaur dig
hotspot.text:
A fossil of a dinosaur showing well preserved teeth.

Why do teeth make better fossils than bone?

They are harder than bone.

hotspot.title: Dinosaur
hotspot.text: Fossilized teeth help us understand the environment, the eating habits, and the digestive process of the dinosaur.\n

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Paleontologist at work with various tools.

hotspot.title: Paleontology
hotspot.text:
A paleontologist studies fossils and prehistoric life to understand the environment and the evolution of organisms. 

Using a combination of science, mathematics, and engineering, a paleontologist works to understand the environment on Earth millions of years ago.

hotspot.title: Paleontologist tools
hotspot.text:
A paleontologist needs a lot of tools to dig out the fossils without damaging them. 

Typical tools include chisels, shovels, picks, and brushes. 

First the fossil is prepared by removing the surrounding rock and debris after excavation. 

Next, the fossil is stabilized to ensure that it can be studied and displayed.

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Ammonites are good index fossils to understand various time periods on Earth.

hotspot.title: Ammonites
hotspot.text:
The word Ammonite is derived from the Greek horn God Ammon. 

This picture shows fossils of squid like creatures with coil shells known as Ammonites. 

They lived over 240 million years ago and went extinct 65 million years ago along with the dinosaurs.

Ammonites are related to octopus, squid, and nautilus.

hotspot.title: Ammonite fossil
hotspot.text: Ammonite fossils make good guide fossils or index fossils.\n\nThe rock layers in which Ammonites are found can be linked to the various time periods on Earth.
